Thanks to my Knight-hood, she's a Lady—

act_1: Bellmour, good Morrow— Why truth on't is, these early Sallies are not usual to me; but Bussiness as you see Sir— And Business must be follow'd, or be lost.
Pleasure, I guess you mean.
Oh the Wise will tell you—
How how, Ned, a wise Man say more than he understands?
In Castles ith' Air of thy own building: That's thy Element Ned— Well as high as a Flyer as you are, I have a Lure may make you stoop.
Hold hold, 'slife that's the wrong.
Ay, or any Body that she's about—
That's pleasant, by my troth from thee, who hast enjoy'd her.
So was true as Turtle— An imagination Ned, ha? Preach this Doctrin to Husbands, and the married Women will adore thee.
But is it not an Abuse to the Lover to be made a Blind of? For she only stalks under him to take aim at her Husband.

It must be a very superstitious Country, where such Zeal passes for true Devotion. I doubt it will be damn'd by all our Protestant Husbands for slat Idolatry— But if you can make Alderman Fondlewife of your Perswasion, this Letter will be needless.
Ay.

Ay, am I not? To be continually starting of Hares for you to Course. We were certainly cut out for one another; for my Temper quits an Amour, just where thine takes it up— But read that, it is an Appointment for me, this Evening; when Fondlewife will be gone out of Town, to meet the Master of a Ship about the return of a Venture which he's in danger of losing. Read, read.
Ay.

Faith I hate Love when 'tis sorced upon a Man; as I do Wine— And this Business is none of my seeking; I only hapned to be once or twice, where, Laetitia was the handsomest Woman in Company, so consequently apply'd my self to her— And it seems she has taken me at my word— Had you been there or any Body 'thad been the same.
Never doubt it; for if the Spirit of Cuckoldom be once raised up in a Woman, the Devil can't lay it, till she has dont.

A kind of Mungril Zealot, sometimes very precise and peevish: But I have seen him pleasant enough in his way; much addicted to Jealousie, but more to Fondness: So that as he is often Jealous without a Cause, he's as often satisfied without Reason.
Ay, you may take him for good and-all if you will, for you have made him sit for no Body else— Well—

Yes, Heartwell, that furly, old, pretended Woman-hater thinks her Vertuous; that's one reason why I fail her: I would have her fret her self out of conceit with me, that she may entertain some Thoughts of him. I know he visits her ev'ry day.
Well good Morrow, let's dine together, I'l meet at the old place.
But I saw my Araminta, yet am as impatient.
act_2: I should rather think Favours, so gain'd, to be due Rewards to indefatigable Devotion— For as Love is a Deity, he must be serv'd by Prayer.
You are the Temples of Love, and 'tis through you, our Devotion must be convey'd.
O Madam—
act_3: He's talking to himself, I think; Prithee lets try if we can hear him
Hust—
Or a young Wench, betwixt pleasure and reputation.
She has made a quarrel on't.
And I love to have the pleasure of making my peace— I should not esteem a Pardon if too easie won.
Could you be content to go to Heaven?
Nor I to marry Araminta till I merit her.
That's true; but I would—
Well, I'le leave you with your Engineer.
act_4: To confirm what I have said read this
'Tis an untimely Fruit, and she has miscarried of her Love.

Yes, when I feed my self— But I hate to be cram'd— By Heav'n there's not a Woman, will give a Man the pleasure of a chase: My sport is always balkt or cut short— I stumble ore the Game I would pursue. — 'Tis dull and unnatural to have a Hare run full in the Hounds Mouth; and would distaste the keenest Hunter— I would have overtaken, not have met my Game.
No, she will be there this evening— Yes I will go too— And she shall see her error in—
I should disappoint her if I did not— By her management I should think she expects it. All Naturally fly what does pursue:'Tis sit Men should be coy, when Women wooe.

Now must I pretend ignorance equal to hers, of what she knows as well as I. Men are apt to offend ('tis true) where they find most Goodness to forgive. — But, Madam, I hope I shall prove of a Temper, not to abuse Mercy, by committing new Offences.
I find, Madam, the Formality of the Law must be observ'd, tho' the Penalty of it be dispens'd with; and an Offender must Plead to his Arraignment, tho' he have his Pardon in his pocket.
Hey day! Which way now? Here's fine doubling.
You have given that Passion a much kinder Epithet than Sawcy, in another place.

Did I dream? Or do I dream? Shall I believe my Eyes, or Ears? The Vision is here still. — Your Passion, Madam, will admit of no farther reasoning. — But here is a silent Witness of your acquaintance. —
That Tongue, which denies what the Hands have done.
No, Madam, I'm gone. — She knows her Name's to it, which she will be unwilling to expose to the Censure of the first finder.
act_5: Sharper swears, she has forsworn the Letter. — I'm sure he tells me Truth; — but I am not sure she told him Truth: — Yet she was unaffectedly concern'd, he says; and often blush'd with Anger and Surprize: — And so I remember in the Park. — She had reason, if I wrong her. — I begin to doubt.
Ha! It has a Colour. — But how do you know it, Sirrah?
And where did you tell her?
There I receiv'd the Letter. — It must be so. — And why did you not find me out, to tell me this before, Sot?
Pox o' my sawcy Credulity. — If I have lost her, I deserve it. But if Confession and Repentance be of force, I'll win her, or weary her into a Forgiveness.
Oh, 'twas Frenzy all: Cannot you forgive it? — Men in Madness have a Title to your Pity.
I am not presuming beyond a Pardon.
What's the matter?
Bellmour, Give it over; you vex him too much; 'tis all serious to him.
Nay, 'tis a Sore of your own scratching. — Well George, —
And if Sylvia had not been your Wife, my Whore might have been just. — There, we are even. — But have a good heart, I heard of your Misfortune, and come to your relief.
What would you give?
Faith, that's a sure way. — But here's one can sell you freedom better cheap.
No signing to a Blank, friend.
Agreed.
Patience. Re-enter Sharper, with Sir Ioseph, Bluffe, Sylvia, Lucy, Setter.
Ay, ay, to this instant Moment. — I have past an Act of Oblivion.
I know whom you have not got; pray Ladies convince him.
— That deserves a Fool with a better Title. — Pray use her as my Relation, or you shall hear on't.
— Ill-natur'd, as an old Maid. —
May I presume to hope so great a Blessing?
